section.title: Rows and columns
section.p:
We can set the stage for matrices using a simple set of two linear equations in two variables, such as
3x \amp + \amp y \amp = 7 -x \amp + 3y \amp = 1 . This system happens to have the unique solution x=2, y=1. We can summarize it in terms of a coefficient matrix
\bA = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 3 \end{bmatrix}
and a vector
\bb = \twovec{7}{1} .
We can interpret the system two different ways, depending on whether we organize by rows (associated with equations) or columns (associated with variables).
Each row of the system is an equation describing a line in the (x,y) plane. The intersection of the lines is the point representing the solution of the system.

program.input:
A = [ 3 1; -1 3 ]; b = [7 ; 1];
fimplicit(@(x,y) A(1,1)*x+A(1,2)*y-b(1),[-1 3]) hold on fimplicit(@(x,y) A(2,1)*x+A(2,2)*y-b(2),[-1 3])
axis([-1 3 -1 3]) plot([0 0],[-1 3],'k-','linewid',2) plot([-1 3],[0 0],'k-','linewid',2)
axis equal, grid on xlabel('x'), ylabel('y')

section.p:
The column viewpoint is less familiar. We interpret the system as an equivalent statement about plane vectors:
x \twovec{3}{-1} + y \twovec{1}{3} = \twovec{7}{1} . We call this a linear combination of the columns of the matrix. Vectors are equal only if all their components are equal, so the meaning is unchanged. But it invites a different picture, interpreting x and y as coefficients and making \bb the target.

Another instructive case is the system
x \amp + \amp 2 y \amp = 1 -2 x \amp - 4 y \amp = -1 .

The row picture makes it clear that we are seeking the intersection of two distinct parallel lines, an enterprise that is bound to disappoint us. Likewise, the column picture (not given) is about finding combinations of the column vectors \twovec{1}{-2} and \twovec{2}{-4}. These too are parallel, so all of their linear combinations lie on a single line through the origin. The given vector \bb=\twovec{1}{1} is not on this line, so no solution exists.

Of course, a different vector on the right-hand side such as \bb=\twovec{-3}{6} does lie on this line, and we can solve the system in this case. In fact, there are infinitely many ways to do it:
\twovec{-3}{6} = -3 \twovec{1}{-2} = \twovec{1}{-2} - 2\twovec{2}{-4} = \cdots.
In this situation, the corresponding row picture still has two parallel lines, but they conincide, indicating the infinite set of solutions.
